Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: The Genetic Basis of Adaptation in the Plant Pathogen Pseudomonas syringae
Award.AbstractNarration:
Bacteria colonize diverse environments, and the various traits that allow them to survive in these different environments are of wide ecological, medical and agricultural relevance. There is thus considerable interest in determining the genetic changes that allow specific strains to flourish in some environments while perishing in others. This project will identify the genes that allow the plant bacterial pathogen Pseudomonas syringae to spread in different environments. The proposed study pairs the comparison of bacterial genomes with comparative functional genetics to identify the specific genes that render P. syringae strains acute pathogens in crop populations and natural plant populations and allow P. syringae to proliferate in soil.
An understanding of the genetic changes that allow bacteria to survive in different environments has important implications because slight genetic changes in a bacterial strain can result in the decimation of entire plant populations or the death of a patient. The cross-disciplinary nature of the project supports the training of undergraduate and graduate students. The project includes outreach and education of K-12 students, including students from underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The genomes of bacterial pathogens that invade different hosts are often composed of very different sets of genes. While many of these genetic differences do not affect a bacterium’s ability to grow in the host, a subset of these genetic differences underlie differences in host specificity. This project aims to identify which of the many  genes that differ between pathogen strains are responsible for adaptation to the host.  Specifically, we are interested in understanding the genes important for the plant pathogen Pseudomonas syringae to infect its host Arabidopsis thaliana. To study this, we performed saturation mutagenesis (knocking out every gene in the genome independently) of a strain of P. syringae and are beginning to screen this mutant library for survival in different environments.

The saturated library we have generated was grown in two conditions, in media and in Arabidopsis thaliana plants. To date, we have sequenced the library grown in media with promising results and are preparing to sequence the library grown in A. thaliana.  With only the data from media, we are currently unable to draw final conclusions. We have validated the mutagenesis screening, observing over 50,000 different mutants, with an average of 130 basepairs between inserstions.

We are currently sequencing the samples collected from the plant. After sequencing, the frequency of each of the mutants within the starting library culture, and after growth in each of the environmental conditions, will be assayed by the amplification of the regions flanking the transposon insertions.

The results from this study will reveal which genes are important for colonization of A. thaliana. Overlaying these results with our previous comparative genomics analyses will indicate the relationship between gene conservation and fitness in P. syringae. This information will be of interest to researchers in microbiology, plant pathology and evolutionary biology.
